messages: f109a63709e702ed304a85e971b0f710 (15:42): Hixie / 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c_ , thanks for the comments.  i'll get to making some changes to web idl late next week, when my current busy patch is over.
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (16:01): JohnResig, 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c, I added a very basic testsuite for selectors api. http://dev.w3.org/cvsweb/2006/webapi/selectors-api-testsuite/
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (16:02): it doesn't test much yet, I'm still in the process of working out the best way to write the framework.
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (16:02): but take a look, see if what I have is a good start and let me know if you have any suggestions for improvements
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (16:04): the plan is to run most tests within an iframe, which loads various HTML and XHTML files, and runs queries on them
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (16:04): and each test is a function within an array, written in tests.js
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:06): Would you have a single iframe, and run each test in it in turn?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:07): Oh, actually, I think I'm just misunderstanding the whole thing, so ignore me
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (16:07): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c, yes, that's most likely
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:07): Are you always testing DOM-created documents, rather than downloaded-over-HTTP documents?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (16:08): no, the plan is to allow each test to either create a document or load a file into the iframe
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:09): Ah, right
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (16:09): not sure exactly how to do that, since such operations would need to be asynchronous
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (16:09): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: I will ask weinig or somebody to tae a look
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (16:09): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: we have our own regression tests for querySelector but I doubt they are very powerful
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:09): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: Run test 1, set onload to a function that checks the results and then runs test 2? Not sure what the problem is :-)

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (16:10): we specifically didn't want to try to make tests for every possible kind of selector including edge cases, though come to think of it that would be more convenient than the tests with red and green boxes usually used for this kind of thing
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (16:10): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c, yeah, something like that could work
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (16:11): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: we have a good test framework for tests that purely involve scripting APIs and not layout
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (16:11): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c, ok. That might be good if I could build on that, instead of creating my own
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:12): Mozilla has a framework for that too
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:12): (http://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/Mochitest )
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (16:12): basically you just write a series of assertions in a JS file like this:
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (16:12): shouldBe("Math.abs(1)", "1");
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (16:12): shouldBe("Math.abs(-1)", "1");
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (16:12): Opera sort of does too, but it's not really something that's usable by anyone easily
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (16:12): and we have some JS files that implement the functions
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (16:13): ours is real easy to use
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (16:13): and gives pretty results
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (16:14): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: I'll mail you an example (unless you have a WebKit checkout handy in which case I could point you to it)

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:14): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: Is it easy to run individual tests by themselves? (Mozilla's Mochitests run a whole web server and a special browser mode, which is annoyingly complex)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (16:15): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: we group tests in files, all it takes to "run" such a suite is to open the html file in any browser
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (16:15): for fully automated execution we have a headless tool that loads all the html files in sequence
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (16:15): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: Okay, sounds good :-)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (16:21): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: the three files starting with js- are the framework
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (16:22): elements-not-in-document.js is the substance of the test case

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (16:22): I might also have a script lying around to generate the wrapper HTML files for the script files (they just include the test script plus the CSS file and two helpers)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (16:23): but it's pretty trivial
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (16:24): makes good looking output though where it is easy to spot the failures and why they fail
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (16:25): in addition to the basic shouldBe tests there's also shouldBeTrue, shouldBeFalse, shouldBeNaN, shouldBeNull, shouldBeUndefined and shouldThrow
